flow.descriptionCdata:
67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.0a62c13a-3b0f-4b99-8fba-a2bee3e88dde.prompt=The cookbook name. 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.1d7ce9c5-e15f-4558-b577-3251b3f9681a.description=
Accepts an object in the JavaScript Object Notation format (JSON) and
returns a value for the specified key.

The JSON format encodes objects as a set of unordered key/value pairs, which is
similar to a structure or map in other programming languages.  For example,
   { "city" \: "Palo Alto", 
     "state" \: "CA" }
is an object with two elements one with the name "city" having the value "Palo
Alto", and the other being the name "state" with the value "CA". This operation would 
return "Palo Alto" if user enters "city" as a key.

If the input object contains JSON array, array index can be used in the key input. For example, 
{ "location"\: [
      {"city"\: "Roseville", "country"\: "United States"},
      {"city"\: "Cluj", "country"\: "Romania"},
      {"city"\: "Yehud", "country"\: "Israel"}]    
}
The operation would return "Roseville" if user enters "location[0].city" as a key.

JavaScript objects are useful for representing structured data, and are
especially when used within an array.  For example, an operation that retrieves
a set of incidents from an external system may return the entire list in one
array of incident objects.  The description of the enclosing folder,
/Library/Utility Operations/Container/JavaScript Objects has more examples, and
the JSON format is described completely at http\://www.json.org.

Inputs

   object
      The JavaScript object.  
      The operation will return a failure if it is not a JavaScript object.

   key
      The key in the object to get the value of.

Responses

   success
      The value was successfully returned for the specified key. 

   failure
      There was some error in processing the object, most likely because the
      object is not in valid JavaScript Object Notation or the specified key does not exist in the object.  
      You may wish to use a tool such as http\://www.jsonlint.com/ to help diagnose problems with
      JavaScript Object Notation.

Outputs

   The primary output will be the value for the specified key in the object.

Note

    If the value in JSON object is in scientific notation, the returned output will be converted to an equivalent decimal number. Ex, 2.9e+1 will be converted to 29.
67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.20143c57-13a5-4d9e-a896-02c4b5b2da1b.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostName 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.2a545ca9-c3fd-456c-a10f-0148957b7050.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostPassword 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.3b305131-5a68-4ad1-9f72-9d155632a392.prompt=Enter a value for cookbookName 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.4aa40cd4-e625-4366-8bad-b704b7010d17.description=
Iterates through a JavaScript array, i.e. a string value that contains an array
in the JavaScript Object Notation format (JSON).  Each time that this operation
is called it places the value of the current array element into the Result
output and advances the iterator to the array element.

The JSON format is basically a way to encode arrays and other values using
JavaScript notation.  For arrays, this means that the values need to be
surrounded by square brackets, and each element in the array can be a string
(which needs surrounding quotes), a number, true, false, null, or a nested array
or object.  Commas are always used as delimiters between array elements, and
they can appear within string elements without confusion.  For example, the
following is a simple JSON array\:
   [ "cat", "dog", "horse" ]
Note that the equivalent OO list would be 
   cat,dog,horse
The benefits of JavaScript arrays are that delimiters are fixed and cannot be
confused with data, and that complex nesting of arrays and objects are
supported.  The description of the enclosing folder, /Library/Utility
Operations/Container/JavaScript Objects has more examples, and the JSON format
is described completely at http\://www.json.org.

Modifying the contents of the array during iteration is not generally supported,
but will be safe as long as the affected item(s) are beyond the current position
of the iterator.  The iterator keeps track of where it is in the array by
position.  If items are added or removed to the list in a position preceding the
iterator, it may cause the iterator to return results that are not obvious.  For
example, if the array contains [ "a", "b", "c" ] and the iterator is positioned
on the second element, "b" and the first element is removed, then the iterator
will now be at the last element in the list, "c".

There is currently a limitation that a flow can only have one of these array
iterator steps active at a time without causing possible conflicts.  In other
words, if you need to iterate through a nested array, you will should use a
sub-flow to process the inner array.  You may have two or more of these array
iterators in the same flow as long as each iterator reaches the end of its array
before the next one begins.

Inputs

   array
      The JavaScript array that will be iterated through.  The operation will
      return a failure if the array is not a JavaScript array; a normal OO list
      is NOT a JavaScript array.

Responses

   has more
      The iterator has not yet reached the end of the array. The Result output
      will be populated with the value of the current element in the array, and
      the iterator will advance to the next element in the array.

   no more
      The iterator has reached the end of the array, and there is no more data
      to return.  The iterator will become undefined after this call, which
      basically will reset it so that if called again, this operation will begin
      another iteration at the beginning of the array.

   failure
      There was some error in iterating through the list, and the Result output
      will contain information about the error.  This will occur if the input
      array is not a valid JavaScript array.  For example, if presented with a
      common list value such as a,b,c it will fail because it lacks the
      enclosing brackets and the quotes around each string element.  You may
      wish to use a tool such as http\://www.jsonlint.com/ to help diagnose
      problems with JavaScript Object Notation.

Outputs

   Result
      The current array element.  When incorporating this operation into a flow,
      you should assign a meaningful result value from this field.  Note that
      since JavaScript arrays may contain nested arrays or other objects, the
      value returned in Result may also require further processing.
67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.4b0614df-4087-4347-a66a-08139450102c.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostUser 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.50f5acac-cb30-438f-8f96-7d57c4489e0c.prompt=Enter a value for responseTimeOut 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.6cfeefc5-191e-4361-8756-f6661e45a6fe.prompt=Enter a value for cookbookName 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.7d67f7dc-2b1e-43f9-91d4-8f4484f7b803.prompt=The path to the chef repository (The chef-repo folder). 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.7f6813dd-c4ec-4ae4-b46e-da3da99625f3.prompt=The name/fqdn of a host which runs Chefs APi client (knife). 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.82574bc4-284a-4d9b-8d9b-e4c75ea846ec.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostUser 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.88472f78-1859-4397-8d08-feed44fae4ca.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostPassword 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.a244518d-2b8a-4c80-9263-101342936f04.prompt=6f0c2422-dd79-447d-af02-a2261dd94973.11d4ea36-ca65-4eb7-b88c-868c61a81f77.prompt 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.a39a6e2a-fdd9-4dff-b85b-b6e6c7818939.prompt=A user name with sufficient rights to run the knife commands. 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.a3a6d900-c029-43e2-b8bd-9b33232f6522.description=\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#Additional Parameters\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\# This operation gets the cookbook details. Inputs\: cookbookName - The cookbook name. responseTimeOut - Time out for the operation, populates the OOB timeout variable. apiHostName - The name/fqdn of a host which runs Chefs APi client (knife). apiHostUser - A user name with sufficient rights to run the knife commands. apiHostPassword - The apiHostUser's password. apiHostRepo - The path to the chef repository (The chef-repo folder). outputFormat - The format of the result. You can use json\text\yaml\pp Outputs\: cookbookVersion - The cookbook version. \#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#Original Description\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\# 
Uses WMI to attempt to create a remote process on a machine.  The command passed should be formatted as though it was run on the command line.

CAUTION\: internally 'cmd /c' gets prepended to the command passed.  Also '2>tempfile 1>tempfile' get appended to the command so that we can attempt to capture stdout and stderr.
So your command will look like this when executed\:
	'cmd /c [yourcommand] 2>temperr 1>tempout'

Inputs\:
    host - Hostname or ip address of the target machine.
    command - The command you want executed. Special characters\: <, >, (, ), & need to be escaped using the caret (^) character.  The only exception to this rule is when the > character is used to redirect output.
    user - Username to use for remote WMI impersonation and thread impersonation on the RAS host for this operation (can be left blank).
    password - Password of the user.
    outputPath - Network accessible path used by the operation to store temporary files. If not specified it points to \\host\admin$\temp\'. If this path is not accessible you should change it to use another share that the host local system account has write access to. By default the path will have to be changed on Windows 2000 systems.
    currentDirectory - Current directory.
    characterSet - The character encoding used to write the batch file that will be remotely executed by the operation. Unicode character encodings may not supported for this input (utf-8, utf-16, etc.).  Support for unicode encodings depends on target system capabilities.  By default this encoding will also be used to read the command output that is redirected to temporary files.  If the command output is expected to be of different encoding, specify the different encoding in the outputCharacterSet input.  Default value\: The encoding of the operating system where is RAS installed.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis
    outputCharacterSet - The character encoding used to read the command output that was redirected to temporary files.  Only need to specify this input if the output of the command is known to output a different character encoding.  As an example\: the 'wmic' command returns utf-16 encoded output.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis, utf-8, utf-16
    timeout - The number of seconds before assuming the remote process is no longer functional. After the timeout has expired the remote process and all child processes will be terminated.
Default value\: 90

Responses\:
    success - Remote process successfully launched and has completed executing.
    failure - Unable to start remote process.

Results\:
    returnResult - Return value from WMI for starting the process (not the exit value of the process).
    processID - The process id of the remote process.
    processReturnCode - The return code of the remote process.
    stdOut - Standard output from the remote process.
    stdErr - Standard error from the remote process.

Notes\: 
List of possible encoding names (Support for the encoding may depend on the version or language of the RAS OS)\:

Encoding Name\:	Description\:
IBM437		OEM United States
DOS-720		Arabic (DOS)
ibm737		Greek (DOS)
ibm775		Baltic (DOS)
ibm850		Western European (DOS)
ibm852		Central European (DOS)
IBM855		OEM Cyrillic
ibm857		Turkish (DOS)
IBM00858		OEM Multilingual Latin I
IBM860		Portuguese (DOS)
ibm861		Icelandic (DOS)
DOS-862		Hebrew (DOS)
IBM863		French Canadian (DOS)
IBM864		Arabic (864)
IBM865		Nordic (DOS)
cp866		Cyrillic (DOS)
ibm869		Greek, Modern (DOS)
shift_jis		Japanese (Shift-JIS)
gb2312		Chinese Simplified (GB2312)
ks_c_5601-1987	Korean
big5		Chinese Traditional (Big5)
utf-16		Unicode
unicodeFFFE		Unicode (Big-Endian)
utf-7		Unicode (UTF-7)
utf-8		Unicode (UTF-8)
utf-32		Unicode (UTF-32)
utf-32BE		Unicode (UTF-32 Big-Endian)
Johab		Korean (Johab)
us-ascii		US-ASCII
koi8-r		Cyrillic (KOI8-R)
euc-jp		Japanese (EUC)
EUC-CN		Chinese Simplified (EUC)
euc-kr		Korean (EUC)
hz-gb-2312		Chinese Simplified (HZ)
GB18030		Chinese Simplified (GB18030)
67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.a5fa95fb-d0f9-4d9c-b278-144c68a50eca.prompt=Enter a value for cookbookVersion 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.b4089012-b1b4-48d8-9650-e552050ce7d0.prompt=Enter a value for responseTimeOut 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.b632c5f4-c1cb-4f28-8717-b0229fc55f8a.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostRepo 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.description=
List a cookbook's recipes.

Inputs\:
cookbookName - The cookbook name.
responseTimeOut - Time out (in seconds) for the operations.
apiHostName - The name/fqdn of a host which runs Chefs APi client (knife).
apiHostUser - A user name with sufficient rights to run the knife commands.
apiHostPassword - The apiHostUser's password.
apiHostRepo - The path to the chef repository (The chef-repo folder).

Outputs\:
recipeList - The list of recipes in the cookbook.
67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.e6f83c6b-9d8b-4c0a-b595-298ab7d95c22.description=\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#Additional Parameters\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\# This operation gets the cookbook recipes Inputs\: cookbookName - The cookbook name. cookbookVersion - The cookbook version. responseTimeOut - Time out for the operation, populates the OOB timeout variable. apiHostName - The name/fqdn of a host which runs Chefs APi client (knife). apiHostUser - A user name with sufficient rights to run the knife commands. apiHostPassword - The apiHostUser's password. apiHostRepo - The path to the chef repository (The chef-repo folder). outputFormat - The format of the result. You can use json\text\yaml\pp \#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#Original Description\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\#\# 
Uses WMI to attempt to create a remote process on a machine.  The command passed should be formatted as though it was run on the command line.

CAUTION\: internally 'cmd /c' gets prepended to the command passed.  Also '2>tempfile 1>tempfile' get appended to the command so that we can attempt to capture stdout and stderr.
So your command will look like this when executed\:
	'cmd /c [yourcommand] 2>temperr 1>tempout'

Inputs\:
    host - Hostname or ip address of the target machine.
    command - The command you want executed. Special characters\: <, >, (, ), & need to be escaped using the caret (^) character.  The only exception to this rule is when the > character is used to redirect output.
    user - Username to use for remote WMI impersonation and thread impersonation on the RAS host for this operation (can be left blank).
    password - Password of the user.
    outputPath - Network accessible path used by the operation to store temporary files. If not specified it points to \\host\admin$\temp\'. If this path is not accessible you should change it to use another share that the host local system account has write access to. By default the path will have to be changed on Windows 2000 systems.
    currentDirectory - Current directory.
    characterSet - The character encoding used to write the batch file that will be remotely executed by the operation. Unicode character encodings may not supported for this input (utf-8, utf-16, etc.).  Support for unicode encodings depends on target system capabilities.  By default this encoding will also be used to read the command output that is redirected to temporary files.  If the command output is expected to be of different encoding, specify the different encoding in the outputCharacterSet input.  Default value\: The encoding of the operating system where is RAS installed.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis
    outputCharacterSet - The character encoding used to read the command output that was redirected to temporary files.  Only need to specify this input if the output of the command is known to output a different character encoding.  As an example\: the 'wmic' command returns utf-16 encoded output.
Examples\: ibm437, shift_jis, utf-8, utf-16
    timeout - The number of seconds before assuming the remote process is no longer functional. After the timeout has expired the remote process and all child processes will be terminated.
Default value\: 90

Responses\:
    success - Remote process successfully launched and has completed executing.
    failure - Unable to start remote process.

Results\:
    returnResult - Return value from WMI for starting the process (not the exit value of the process).
    processID - The process id of the remote process.
    processReturnCode - The return code of the remote process.
    stdOut - Standard output from the remote process.
    stdErr - Standard error from the remote process.

Notes\: 
List of possible encoding names (Support for the encoding may depend on the version or language of the RAS OS)\:

Encoding Name\:	Description\:
IBM437		OEM United States
DOS-720		Arabic (DOS)
ibm737		Greek (DOS)
ibm775		Baltic (DOS)
ibm850		Western European (DOS)
ibm852		Central European (DOS)
IBM855		OEM Cyrillic
ibm857		Turkish (DOS)
IBM00858		OEM Multilingual Latin I
IBM860		Portuguese (DOS)
ibm861		Icelandic (DOS)
DOS-862		Hebrew (DOS)
IBM863		French Canadian (DOS)
IBM864		Arabic (864)
IBM865		Nordic (DOS)
cp866		Cyrillic (DOS)
ibm869		Greek, Modern (DOS)
shift_jis		Japanese (Shift-JIS)
gb2312		Chinese Simplified (GB2312)
ks_c_5601-1987	Korean
big5		Chinese Traditional (Big5)
utf-16		Unicode
unicodeFFFE		Unicode (Big-Endian)
utf-7		Unicode (UTF-7)
utf-8		Unicode (UTF-8)
utf-32		Unicode (UTF-32)
utf-32BE		Unicode (UTF-32 Big-Endian)
Johab		Korean (Johab)
us-ascii		US-ASCII
koi8-r		Cyrillic (KOI8-R)
euc-jp		Japanese (EUC)
EUC-CN		Chinese Simplified (EUC)

67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.f80b7072-8583-4961-8e44-45b70fca1713.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostRepo 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.f920ad92-e363-4d4a-b895-2e9483113775.prompt=Enter a value for apiHostName 67d03277-8e6a-4e8c-9b16-53db43c2874a.fdf6e8c3-a864-40c0-8508-73d1f4c951cb.prompt=The apiHostUser's password.
flow.name: Get Cookbook Recipes
